item.title: Comment on Why You Never Improve Your Tennis Game â€“ And How You Can by Rashidah
item.dc:creator: Rashidah
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/why-you-never-improve-your-tennis-game-and-how-you-can/#comment-1281">David Hopkins</a>.
Older players can surprise you. I admire the 70 and 80 year olds at our local court who can still serve well and our volleys away. They don't move a lot, but with good stroke form, they can still be an asset on the doubles court. Tennis is a lifelong sport. I played 3 sets today, did the grocery shopping, and cleaned my house and I am 56! Yes, I'm tired but as they say," there is plenty of time to sleep in the grave." Just get moving!

item.title: Comment on Why You Never Improve Your Tennis Game â€“ And How You Can by David Hopkins
item.dc:creator: David Hopkins
item.description: Your comments about older club players lack of physical ability at being able to hit the ball really hard -"they just don't have it in them" inspired me. As a 64 year old who only started playing tennis a year ago your comments could have made me give up, put my racket on e-bay and take up Bowls or competitive crochet. What I might lack in physical ability I make up for in guts and determination and I can still get around the court quicker than a lot of players half my age. As a new player its technique that's my issue, but I can fix that. I'm not looking to compete on the ATP tour so with respect I'll ignore your comments and keep playing, doing my best to prove you wrong. I'm also assuming that you don't coach and take the money from older clients that you know will never be any good.

item.title: Comment on What Gym Exercises Will Improve My Tennis Serve? by Phil
item.dc:creator: Phil
item.description: I like the article and I will try this with a positive approach. I am 69 and a bit heavy but I still play singles. Years back I beat the number one 4.5 singles player in USTA regionals so at best I was a so so 5.0 player but mostly 4.5 and at my age now a 4.0. I am tall (6'3" ) and I used to hit a 108 mph serve. I struggle to reach 80 mph now. Some older and shorter players hit bigger serves so I am a little annoyed.

item.title: Comment on How To Overcome A Plateau In Tennis by craig
item.dc:creator: craig
item.description:
Hi - thanks for this article. Did the sprint session this morning :)
I am exactly as you mention here. Plateau'd after 1.5yrs playing at average club level; and frankly really frustrated. For me the worst thing is losing technique. You briefly mentioned at the end there about consistently maintaining skills; but I've been focusing on backhand for couple months and now can no longer seem to hit good forehand; or my serve flow/groove has just gone - not only flagging; but literally have lost it. Makes me want to quit. Do you have any tips on this for someone who does not have 2hrs/day to keep training all strokes? Some days I honestly feel like I am playing about the same as I was 1.5yrs ago!
